awd_titl_txt: The Geometry, Topology and Number Theory of the Jones Polynomial
awd_abstract_narration:
Knot theory is the study of 3-dimensional shapes obtained by removing loops from the 3-dimensional space. Microscopic examples of knotted loops appear abundantly in solid state physics, biology (notably, the DNA molecule) and various models of quantum computing. Macroscopic knotted loops occur in the shapes of galaxies, black holes and plasma physics. The proposed research focuses on the theoretical aspects of knot theory and more precisely on the relation between classical and quantum knot invariants. Quantum topology offers a classification of knots by various measures of complexity, for example by using the Jones polynomial of a knot (and its parallels). Understanding this filtering leads to deep connections between knot theory and hyperbolic geometry, number theory, complex analysis, algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. An important aspect of this research is the training of graduate students and the collaboration with senior researchers. The research involves difficult numerical experiments and leads to unexpected discoveries of conjectures and proofs. Aside from mathematics and mathematical physics, quantum knot theory is a powerful and effective tool with the potential to impact topological quantum computation and the study of the shape of long molecules.

Classical knot invariants include the incompressible and normal surface invariants by W. Haken, the character varieties of algebraic geometry and mathematical physics and the hyperbolic geometry approach to 3-dimensional manifolds initiated by W. Thurston. The birth of quantum topology was the Jones polynomial in the mid eighties. The discovery of the Jones polynomial attracted mathematicians and physicists of the highest caliber, including the Fields Medalists V. Jones, E. Witten, V. Drinfeld and M. Kontsevich. There are precise, numerically testable conjectures that relate classical and quantum invariants. Progress on these conjectures (which include the Volume Conjecture of Kashaev, the Slope Conjecture and the AJ Conjecture) is the focus of the proposed research. A combination of numerical experimentation with proofs leads to deep connections between low dimensional topology and hyperbolic geometry, number theory, complex analysis, algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. This combination helps to train young researchers, and to make connections with senior researchers in diverse fields.

por.por_cntn:
Knot theory, classical and quantum, has played an important role  only only in mathematics and mathematical physics, but also  in biology, computer science and physics and mathematics. In biology,  knotted structures  appear in the DNA molecule, the backbone of life, during its replication. Chirality (or left versus right handeness) is an important component of  protein building, as well as of most organic chemistry. In computer science, knots are an integral part of quantum computing and play a key role in  entanglement. In physics, knots appear in plasma physics, as well as in theories that explain particles beyond the standard model. In mathematics, knot theory is a well-established part of 3-dimensional geometry and topology.

The birth of quantum knot theory coincides with V. Jones's discovery of his famous knot polynomial. The Jones polynomial put knot theory in contact with diverse branches of mathematics, including number theory,  representation theory, and asymptotics, and has opened new directions for research.

INTELLECTUAL MERITS: The project focused on problems relating the geometry, topology, number theory and physics of the Jones polynomial of a knot. An important conjecture in this subject  asserts a deep connection between the asymptotics of the (colored) Jones polynomial and the volume of the ambient space, taken with respect to a hyperbolic metric. The PI and the co-PI have substantial results on the formulation and proof of long-standing conjectures on this area.

Aside for the connections between quantum topology and hyperbolic geometry,  the PI and the co-PI developed connections between knot theory and number theory, and connections between knot theory and functional analysis of infinite covers of the knot complement. These connections have far-reaching consequences.

BROADER IMPACTS: The PI and co-PI have supervised PhD theses, and mentored two post-doctoral fellows during the span of this grant. The PI and co-PI are currently advising three more Ph.D. students.

The PI and the co-PI have been a co-organizer in three conferences in Vietnam and in Switzerland. During the span of the grant, the PI and the co-PI have given over 50 presentations of their research results in invited seminars and international conferences, and have given minicourses at many workshops, contributing to the education of PhD students and young post-docs all over the world. The PI and the co-PI have been co-organizers of several international conferences and workshops and of a thematic trimester  focusing on the reserach of the co-PI in Toulouse, France.  Finally, the research funded by the grant, has resulted in 31 publications.
